greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: a(n) = the largest k such that (k+1)! divides n; the number of trailing zeros in the factorial base representation of n (A007623(n)).
comment: Many of the comments given in A055881 apply also here.
The asymptotic density of the occurrences of k is (k+1)/(k+2)!.
The asymptotic mean of this sequence is e - 2 = 0.718281... (A001113 - 2). (End)
link: Antti Karttunen, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..10080
Tyler Ball, Joanne Beckford, Paul Dalenberg, Tom Edgar, and Tina Rajabi, Some Combinatorics of Factorial Base Representations, J. Int. Seq., Vol. 23 (2020), Article 20.3.3.
Index entries for sequences related to factorial base representation
example: In factorial number base representation (A007623), the numbers from 1 to 9 are represented as:
n  A007623(n)  a(n) (gives the number of trailing zeros)
mathematica: With[{b = MixedRadix[Range[12, 2, -1]]}, Array[LengthWhile[Reverse@ IntegerDigits[#, b], # == 0 &] &, 105]] (* _Michael De Vlieger_, Jun 03 2020 *)
program: (define (A230403 n) (if (zero? n) 0 (let loop ((n n) (i 2)) (cond ((not (zero? (modulo n i))) (- i 2)) (else (loop (/ n i) (1+ i)))))))
xref: A few sequences related to factorial base representation (A007623): A034968, A084558, A099563, A060130, A227130, A227132, A227148, A227149, A153880.
Analogous sequence for binary system: A007814.
results.author: _Antti Karttunen_, Oct 31 2013
